characters: FUSE OVER CHIEF'S USE OF FUNDS FOR EL MACANDO LOVE NEST."
ONE RED AND ONE WHITE TAILLIGHT
JULIAN CROSS AS THE AQUEDUCT CLEARS THE SANTA SUSANNAH PA
VOTE YES NOVEMBER 6... CITIZENS COMMITTEE TO SAVE OUR CIT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CURLY drops the photos on Gittes' desk. Curly towers over GITTES and sweats heavily through his workman's clothes, breathing progressively more labored. A drop plunks on Gi shiny desk top. Gittes notes it. A fan whiffs overhead. Gittes glances up it. He looks cool and brisk in a white linen suit despite the heat. Never taking his eyes off Curly, he lights a  cigarette using a lighter with a "nail" on his desk. Curly, with another anguished sob, turns and rams his fis into the wall, kicking the wastebasket as he does. He sta to sob again, slides along the wall where his fist has le a noticeable dent and its impact has sent the signed phot of several movie stars askew. Curly slides on into the blinds and sinks to his knees. H is weeping heavily now, and is in such pain that he actua bites into the blinds. Gittes doesn't move from his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, enough is enough. You  can't eat the Venetian blinds, Curly.  I just had 'em installed on Wednesday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curly responds slowly, rising to his feet, crying. Gittes reaches into his desk and pulls out a shot glass, quickly selects a cheaper bottle of bourbon from several fifths o more expensive whiskeys. Gittes pours a large shot. He shoves the glass across his desk toward Curly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down the hatch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curly stares dumbly at it. Then picks it up, and drains i He sinks back into the chair opposite Gittes, begins to c quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drinking, relaxing a  little) She's just no good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I tell you, Kid? You're  right. When you're right, you're  right, and you're right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't worth thinking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes leaves the bottle with Curly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're absolutely right, I wouldn't  give her another thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pouring himself) You know, you're okay, Mr. Gittes. I  know it's your job, but you're okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (settling back,  breathing a little  easier) Thanks, Curly. Call me Jake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. You know something, Jake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that, Curly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll kill her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. DUFFY & WALSH'S OFFICE Noticeably less plush than Gitte's. A well-groomed, dark- haired WOMAN sits nervously between their two desks, fidd with the veil on her pillbox hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping Mr. Gittes could see to  this personally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost the manner of  someone comforting  the bereaved) If you'll allow us to complete our  preliminary questioning, by then  he'll be free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is the SOUND of ANOTHER MOAN coming from Gittes' Of Something made of glass shatters. The Woman grows more ed INT. GITTES' OFFICE В– GITTES & CURLY Gittes and Curly stand in front of the desk, Gittes stari contemptuously at the heavy breathing hulk towering over  him. Gittes takes a handkerchief and wipes away the plunk perspiration on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crying) They don't kill a guy for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh they don't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for your wife. That's the  unwritten law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes pounds the photos on the desk, shouting;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you the unwritten law, you  dumb son of a bitch, you gotta be  rich to kill somebody, anybody and  get away with it. You think you got  that kind of dough, you think you  got that kind of class?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Curly shrinks back a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet your ass you don't. You can't  even pay me off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This seems to upset Curly even more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll pay the rest next trip. We only  caught sixty ton of skipjack around  San Benedict. We hit a chubasco,  they don't pay you for skipjack the  way they do for tuna or albacore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (easing him out of  his office) Forget it. I only mention it to  illustrate a point...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's now walking him past SOPHIE who pointedly averts her gaze. He opens the door where on the pebbled glass can be read: "J. J. GITTES and Associates. DISCREET INVESTIGATIO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want your last dime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws an arm around Curly and flashes a dazzling smil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) What kind of guy do you think I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Mr. Gittes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me Jake. Careful driving home,  Curly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shuts the door on him and the smile disappears. He shakes his head, starting to swear under his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Mrs. Mulwray is waiting for you,  with Mr. Walsh and Mr. Duffy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes nods, walks on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walsh rises when Gittes enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Mulwray, may I present Mr.  Gittes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes walks over to her and again flashes a warm, sympat smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you do, Mrs. Mulwray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gittes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Mrs. Mulwray, what seems to be  the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds her breath. The revelation isn't easy for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My husband, I believe, is seeing  another woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes looks mildly shocked. He turns for confirmation to his two partners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gravely) No, really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes pulls up a chair sitting next to Mrs. Mulwray betw Duffy and Walsh. Duffy cracks his gum. Gittes gives him an irritated glance. Duffy stops chewing

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't we talk about this alone, Mr.  Gittes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid not, Mrs. Mulwray. These  men are my operatives and at some  point they're going to assist me. I  can't do everything myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, what makes you certain he is  involved with someone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Mulwray hesitates. She seems uncommonly nervous at t question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wife can tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Mulwray, do you love your  husband?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shocked) ...Yes of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deliberately) Then go home and forget about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring intently at  her) I'm sure he loves you, too. You know  the expression, let sleeping dogs  lie? You're better off not knowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with some real anxiety) But I have to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her intensity is genuine. Gittes looks to his two partner

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, what's your husband's  first name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hollis. Hollis Mulwray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (visibly surprised) Water and Power?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Mulwray nods, almost shyly. Gittes is now casually b carefully checking out the detailing of Mrs. Mulwray's dr В– her handbag, shoes, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the Chief Engineer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little eagerly) Chief Engineer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes' glance tells Duffy Gittes wants to do the questio Mrs. Mulwray nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confidentially) This type of investigation can be  hard on your pocketbook, Mrs. Mulwray.  It takes time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money doesn't matter to me, Mr.  Gittes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well. We'll see what we can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Already shimmering with heat. A drunk blows his nose with his fingers into the fountain the foot of the steps. Gittes, impeccably dressed, passes the drunk on the way u the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Former Mayor SAM BAGBY is speaking. Behind him is a huge  map, with overleafs and bold lettering: "PROPOSED ALTO VALLEJO DAM AND RESERVOIR"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the councilmen are reading funny papers and gossi columns while Bagby is speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, today you can walk out  that door, turn right, hop on a  streetcar and in twenty-five minutes  end up smack in the Pacific Ocean.  Now you can swim in it, you can fish  in it, you can sail in it but you  can't drink it, you can't water your  lawns with it, you can't irrigate an  orange grove with it.  Remember we  live next door to the ocean but we  also live on the edge of the desert.  Los Angeles is a desert community.  Beneath this building, beneath every  street there's a desert. Without  water the dust will rise up and cover  us as though we'd never existed! (pausing, letting the  implication sink in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sitting next to some grubby farmers, bored. He yawns, edg away from one of the dirtier farmers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) The Alto Vallejo can save us from  that, and I respectfully suggest  that eight and a half million dollars  is a fair price to pay to keep the  desert from our streets and not on  top of them.

dialogues.speaker: AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: An amalgam of farmers, businessmen, and city employees ha been listening with keen interest. A couple of the farmer applaud. Somebody shooshes them.

dialogues.speaker: COUNCIL COMMITTEE
dialogues.text: In a whispered conference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (acknowledging Bagby) Mayor Bagby... let's hear from the  departments again. I suppose we better  take Water and Power first. Mr.  Mulwray.

dialogues.speaker: REACTION
dialogues.text: Looking up with interest from his racing form.

dialogues.speaker: MULWRAY
dialogues.text: Walks to the huge map with overleafs. He is a slender man his sixties, who wears glasses and moves with surprising  fluidity. He turns to a smaller, younger man, and nods. T man turns the overleaf on the map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In case you've forgotten, gentlemen,  over five hundred lives were lost  when the Van der Lip Dam gave way  core samples have shown that beneath  this bedrock is shale similar to the  permeable shale in the Van der Lip  disaster.  It couldn't withstand  that kind of pressure there. (referring to a new  overleaf) Now you propose yet another dirt  banked terminus dam with slopes of  two and one half to one, one hundred  twelve feet high and a twelve thousand  acre water surface. Well, it won't  hold. I won't build it. It's that  simple. I am not making that kind of  mistake twice. Thank you, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mulwray leaves the overleaf board and sits down. Suddenly there are some whoops and hollers from the rear of the  chambers and a redfaced FARMER drives in several scrawny, bleating sheep. Naturally, they cause a commotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting to farmer) What in the hell do you think you're  doing? (as the sheep bleat  down the aisles toward  the Council) Get those goddam things out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (right back) Tell me where to take them! You don't  have an answer for that so quick, do  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bailiffs and sergeants-at-arms respond to the imprecation of the Council and attempt to capture the sheep and the  farmers, having to restrain one who looks like he's going bodily attack Mulwray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through above, to  Mulwray) You steal the water from the valley,  ruin the grazing, starve my livestock  who's paying you to do that, Mr.  Mulwray, that's what I want to know!

dialogues.speaker: L.A. RIVERBED
dialogues.text: It's virtually empty. Sun blazes off it's ugly concrete b Where the banks are earthen, they are parched and choked  with weeds. After a moment, Mulwray's car pulls INTO VIEW on a flood  control road about fifteen feet above the riverbed. Mulwr gets out of the car. Me looks around.

dialogues.speaker: WITH GITTES
dialogues.text: Holding a pair of binoculars, downstream and just above t flood control road using some dried mustard weeds for cov He watches while Mulwray makes his way down to the center the riverbed. There Mulwray stops, tuns slowly, appears to be looking a the bottom of the riverbed, or at nothing at all.

dialogues.speaker: GITTES
dialogues.text: Trains the binoculars on him. Sun glints off Mulwray's  glasses.

dialogues.speaker: BELOW GITTES
dialogues.text: There's the SOUND of something like champagne corks poppi Then a small Mexican boy atop a swayback horse rides it i the riverbed, and into Gitte's view.

dialogues.speaker: MULWRAY
dialogues.text: Himself stops, stands still when he hears the sound. Powe lines and the sun are overhead, the trickle of brackish w at his feet. He moves swiftly downstream in the direction of the sound toward Gittes.

dialogues.speaker: GITTES
dialogues.text: Moves a little further back as Mulwray rounds the bend in the river and comes face to face with the Mexican boy on muddy banks. Mulwray says something to the boy. The boy doesn't answer at first. Mulwray points to the gr The boy gestures. Mulwray frowns. He kneels down in the m and stares at it. He seems to be concentrating on it. After a moment, he rises, thanks the boy and heads swiftl back upstream В– scrambling up the bank to his car. There he reaches through the window and pulls out a roll blueprints or something like them. He spreads them on the hood of his car and begins to scribble some notes, lookin downstream from time to time. The power lines overhead HUM. He stops, listens to them then rolls up the plans and get back in the car. He drives off.

dialogues.speaker: GITTES
dialogues.text: Hurries to get back to his car. He gets in and gets right back out. The steamy leather burns him. He takes a towel from the b seat and carefully places it on the front one. He gets in and takes off.

dialogues.speaker: POINT FERMIN PARK
dialogues.text: Street lights go on.

dialogues.speaker: MULWRAY
dialogues.text: Pulls up, parks. Hurries out of the car, across the park  lawn and into the shade of some trees and buildings.

dialogues.speaker: GITTES
dialogues.text: Pulls up, moves across the park at a different angle, but the direction Mulwray had gone. He makes it through the t in time to see Mulwray scramble adroitly down the side of the cliff to the beach below. Be seems in a hurry. Gittes moves after him, having a little more difficulty negotiat the climb than Mulwray did.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN ON THE BEACH
dialogues.text: Gittes looks to his right where the bay is a long, clear  crescent. He looks to his left. There's a promontory of sorts. It's apparent Mulwray has gone that way. Gittes hesitates, the moves in that direction but climbs along the promontory i order to be above Mulwray.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE OUTFALL
dialogues.text: Gittes spots Mulwray just below him, kicking at the sand. Mulwray picks up a starfish. Brushes the sand off it. Loo absently up toward Gittes.

dialogues.speaker: GITTES
dialogues.text: Backs away, sits near the outfall, yawns.

dialogues.speaker: BEACON LIGHT AT POINT FERMIN
dialogues.text: Flashing in the dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting, suddenly starts. He swears softly. He's in a pud of water and the seat of his trousers is wet.

dialogues.speaker: MULWRAY
dialogues.text: Below him in watching the water trickling down from the  outfall near Gittes. Mulwray stands and stares at the water, apparently fascin Even as Gittes watches Mulwray watching, the volume and  velocity seem to increase until it gushes in spurts, casc into the sea, whipping it into a foam.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE STREET
dialogues.text: There's a slip of paper stuck under the windshield wiper. Gittes pulls it off, gets in the car and turns on the das light. It says:

dialogues.speaker: VOTE YES NOVEMBER 6... CITIZENS COMMITTEE TO SAVE OUR CIT
dialogues.text: HON. SAM BAGBY, FORMER MAYOR В– CHAIRMAN." Gittes grumble crumples it up and tosses it out the window. He notices o flyers parked on a couple of cars down the street. Gittes reaches down and opens his glove compartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Consists of a small mountain of Ingersoll pocket watches. The cheap price tags are still on them. Gittes pulls out  one. He absently winds it, checks the time with his own watch. It's 9:37 as he walks to Mulwray's car and places it behi the front wheel of Mulwray's car. He yawns again and head back to his own car.

dialogues.speaker: GITTES
dialogues.text: Arrives whistling, opens the door with "J.J. GITTES AND  ASSOCIATES В– DISCREET INVESTIGATION" on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Sophie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophie hands him a small pile of messages. He goes throug them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walsh here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in the dark room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes walks through his office to Duffy and Walsh's. A l red light is on in the corner, over a closed door. Gittes walks over and knocks on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd he go yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three reservoirs. Men's room of a  Richfield gas station on Flower, and  the Pig 'n Whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, this guy's really got  water on the brain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you expect? That's his job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, we can't string this broad  out indefinitely we got to come up  with something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I got something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? You pick up the watch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. DUFFY & WALSH'S OFFICE В– GITTES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's on your desk. Say, you hear the  one about the guy who goes to the  North Pole with Admiral Byrd looking  for penguins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes walks to his office.

dialogues.speaker: ON HIS DESK
dialogues.text: Is the Ingersoll watch, the crystal broken, the hands sto at 2:47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was there all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes drops it, sits down. Walsh comes in carrying a ser of wet photos stuck with clothes pins onto a small blackb

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; eagerly) So what you got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walsh shows him the photos. He looks at them. They are a  series outside a restaurant showing Mulwray with another whose appearance is striking. In two of the photos a gnar cane is visible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; obviously  annoyed) This?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got into a terrific argument  outside the Pig 'n Whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. The traffic was pretty  loud. I only heard one thing В– apple  core.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apple core?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes tosses down the photos in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, Walsh. That's what you  spent your day doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, you tell me to take pictures,  I take pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me explain something to you,  Walsh. This business requires a  certain finesse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PHONE has been RINGING. Sophie buzzes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Sophie? (he picks up the phone) Duffy, where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duffy's VOICE can be HEARD, excitedly. "I got it. I got i He's found himself some cute little twist in a rowboat, i Echo Park."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Okay, slow down В– Echo Park. (to Walsh) Jesus, water again.

dialogues.speaker: WESTLAKE PARK, (MCARTHUR PARK)
dialogues.text: Duffy is rowing, Gittes seated in the stern. They pass Mulwray and a slender blonde girl in a summer p dress, drifting in their rowboat, Mulwray fondly doting o the girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Duffy, as they  pass) Let's have a big smile, pal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shoots past Duffy, expertly running off a couple of fa shots. Mulwray and the girl seem blissfully unaware of them.

dialogues.speaker: DUFFY
dialogues.text: Turns again and they row past Mulwray and the girl, Gitte again clicking off several fast shots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVE ALONG the red tiled roof and down to a lower level o the roof where Gittes' feet are hooked over the apex of t roof and Gittes himself is stretched face downward on the tiles, pointing himself and his camera to a veranda below him where the girl and Mulwray are eating. Gittes is clic off more shots when the tiles his feet are hooked over co loose. Gittes begins a slow slide down the tile to the edge of t roof and possibly over it to a three-story drop. He tries slow himself down. The loose tile also begins to slide. Gittes stops himself at the roof's edge by the storm drai and begins a very precarious turn, this time hooking his  feet in the drain itself. The loose tile falls and hits t veranda below. He stops as it's about to slide over the e He carefully lays it in the drain. But a fragment off the cracked edge of the tile falls.

dialogues.speaker: WITH MULWRAY AND THE GIRL
dialogues.text: Mulwray staring at the fragment at his feet. He looks to girl. He's clearly concerned. He rises, looks up to the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The roof and the sign topping it betray nothing. He slowl sits back down, staring at the tile fragment.

dialogues.speaker: FUSE OVER CHIEF'S USE OF FUNDS FOR EL MACANDO LOVE NEST."
dialogues.text: In the style of the Hearst yellow press, there is a heart shaped drawing around one of the photos that Gittes had t Next to it is a smaller column, "J.J. Gittes hired by  suspicious spouse."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holds the paper and reads while getting his haircut and h shoes shined. In fact, almost all the customers are readi papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gittes) When you get so much publicity, after  a while you must get blasГ© about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A self-satisfied smile comes to Gittes' face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Face it. You're practically a movie  star.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In b.g., customers can be OVERHEARD talking about the dro Interspersed with above, someone is saying, "They're gonn start rationing water unless it rains." Someone else says "Only for washing your cars." Third says, "You're not goi to be able to water your lawn either, or take a bath more than once a week." First says, "If you don't have a lawn a car, do you get an extra bath?" Gittes has been staring outside the barbershop. A car is  stalled. The hood is up. A man watches his radiator boiling over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Look at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heat's murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (end of conversation) Fools names and fools faces...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes has heard the word. He straightens up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling; to Other  Customer) What's that, pal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating paper) Nothing. You got a hell of a way to  make a living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh? What do you do to make ends meet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mortgage Department, First National  Bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me, how many people a week do  you foreclose on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't publish a record in the  paper, I can tell you that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither do I.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you have a press agent do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes gets out of the chair. Barney, a little concerned, tries to restrain him, holding onto the barber sheet arou Gittes' neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney, who is this bimbo? He a  regular customer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy, Jake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, pal. I make an honest living.  People don't come to me unless they're  miserable and I help 'em out of a  bad situation. I don't kick them out  of their homes like you jerks who  work in the bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake, for Christ's sake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes is trying to take off his sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, get out of the barber chair.  We'll go outside and talk this over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Customer is shrinking back into the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, c'mon, Jake. Sit down. Sit down.  You hear about the fella goes to his  friend and says, 'What'll I do, I'm  tired of screwing my wife?' and his  friend says, 'Whyn't you do what the  Chinese do?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes allows himself to be tugged back to his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how that got in the  paper as a matter of fact В– it  surprised me it was so quick. I make  an honest living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Course you do, Jake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An honest living.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) So anyway, he says, 'whyn't you do  what the Chinese do?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes comes bursting in, slapping a newspapers on his th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Duffy, Walsh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walsh comes out of his office, Duffy out of the other one

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Sophie, go to the little girl's room  for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, Mr. Gittes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (insisting) Sophie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Gittes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So there's this fella who's tired of  screwing his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake, listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Duffy, you're always in a  hurry and his friend says why not do  what the Chinese do? So he says what  do they do? His friend says the  Chinese they screw for a while. Just  listen a second, Duffy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stunning YOUNG WOMAN appears behind Gittes in his doorw She's shortly joined by a small, GRAY-HAIRED MAN. They li unseen by Gittes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...and then they stop and they read  a little Confucius and they screw  some more and they stop and they  smoke some opium and then they go  back and screw some more and they  stop again and they contemplate the  moon or something and it makes it  more exciting. So this other guy  goes home to screw his wife and after  a while he stops and gets up and  goes into the other room only he  reads Life Magazine and he goes back  and he screws some more and suddenly  says excuse me a second and he gets  up and smokes a cigarette and he  goes back and by this time his wife  is getting sore as hell. So he screws  some more and then he gets up to  look at the moon and his wife says,  'What the hell do you think you're  doing? (Gittes breaks up) ...you're screwing like a Chinaman.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes hangs onto Sophie's desk laughing his ass off. The little Gray-Haired Man winces. When Gittes looks up he se the Young Woman, apparently in her late twenties. She's s stunning that Gittes nearly gasps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gittes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I think I... I would've  remembered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have we ever met?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I thought. You see, I'm  Mrs. Evelyn Mulwray. You know, Mr.  Mulwray's wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes is staggered. He glances down at the newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that Mulwray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that Mulwray, Mr. Gittes. And  since you agree with me we've never  met, you must also agree that I  haven't hired you to do anything.  Certainly not spy on my husband. I  see you like publicity, Mr. Gittes.  Well, you're going to get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now wait a minute, Mrs. Mulwray...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's walked past him toward the door. He stop her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...there's some misunderstanding  here. It's not going to do any good  to get tough with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn flashes a cold smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get tough with anybody, Mr.  Gittes.  My lawyer does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn starts out the door and Gittes starts after her. T time he's stopped by the Gray-Haired Man who has also com out of his office and up behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's something for you, Mr. Gittes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes turns to be handed a thick sheaf of papers, a summ and complaint. Evelyn walks out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; pleasantly) I suppose we'll be hearing from your  attorney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes stares down at the papers in his hand. INT. GITTES' INNER OFFICE В– GITTES, DUFFY & WALSH On Gittes' desk. There are empty coffee cups, the summons and complaint, and the newspaper Gittes had brought with from the barber shop. The three men are sitting, worn and silent. Walsh chewing gum is the loudest noise in the room. Gittes looks to Walsh with obvious irritation. Walsh stop chewing. Duffy puts out a cigarette in the dregs of one of the cof cups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Duffy) There's seven ashtrays in this room,  Duffy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a filthy habit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said okay, Jake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah. If she'd come in here  saying she was Shirley Temple you'd  say okay to that, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Jake. She gave us Mulwray's  real phone number and address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All she needed for that was the phone  book!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. She said not to call, her  husband might answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I find out who that phony bitch  was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes is staring down at the newspaper. He suddenly grab the phone, begins dialing. A tight little smile breaks ou on his face. He buzzes Sophie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Gittes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me the Times. Whitey Mehrholtz. (as he waits) And how about that snotty broad? (the phone to his ear) What does she think, she's perfect?  Coming in waving her lawyers and her  money at me В– so goddam smug. She's  no better than anybody else in this  town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophie BUZZES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Whitey, what's new, pal?... Yeah,  listen, where did you get those  photographs... Yeah, blowing a fuse  over the El Macando love nest.  That's  cute, Whitey... so who sent them to  you... I sent them? (Gittes laughs a little  hysterically) Why would I be asking how you got  them if I sent them?... Whitey?...  Whitey?... C'mon, level with me for  once, my tit's in the wringer and  it's beginning to hurt... yeah...   yeah... yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he says you sent them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment) They're all a bunch of phonies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. DEPARTMENT WATER & POWER В– HALL Gittes stops outside a door marked: "HOLLIS J. MULWRAY CHIEF ENGINEER"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters an outer office. The SECRETARY looks surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Mulwray, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not in, Mr.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I ask what this is regarding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's personal. Has he been out long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee whiz. (he glances at his  watch) And I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was expecting you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen minutes ago. Why don't I go  in and wait?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without waiting for a response, he does. The Secretary ha rises in protest but Gittes is through the inner door.

dialogues.speaker: MULWRAY'S INNER OFFICE
dialogues.text: The walls are covered with commendation, photos of Mulwra at various construction sites, large maps of watershed ar and reservoirs in the city. On the desk is a framed, tint photo of Evelyn in riding clothes. Gittes moves to the desk, watching the translucent pane i the upper half of the door leading to the outer office as does. He begins to open and close the desk drawers after quickl examining the top. He tries one of the drawers and it doe open. He reopens the top drawer, and the bottom one opens. He looks in it, pulls out a checkbook. He opens it, riffl through the stubs like he was shuffling cards. Drops it,  finds a set of keys, an old phone book, and a menu from a Water Department lunch at the Biltmore Hotel in 1913. The He flips through them, reads one notation in Mulwray's ne hand: "Tues. night. Oak Pass Res. 7 channels used."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes spots a shadow looming in front of the translucent pane. He quickly tosses item after item back, kneeing the drawer, nearly knocking a spare pair of Mulwray's glasses off the desk top when he does. He catches them, puts them the desk and is pacing the room as the door opens.

dialogues.speaker: RUSS YELBURTON
dialogues.text: Enters the room. An anxious Secretary is right behind him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you? (extending his hand) Russ Yelburton, Deputy Chief in the  Department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (equally pleasant) J.J. Gittes. And it's not a  departmental matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if you'd care to wait in my  office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is more a request than an invitation. Gittes nods,  follows Yelburton out, through the outer office to his of down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; as they're  going) You see, this whole business in the  paper with Mr. Mulwray has us all on  edge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smaller than Mulwray's, he has most noticeably a lacquere marlin mounted on the wall. There are a couple of other  pictures of Yelburton with yellowtail and other fish he's standing beside. There's also a small burgee of a fish with the initials A below it, tacked onto the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After all, you work with a man for a  certain length of time, you come to  know him, his habits, his values,  and so forth. Well either he's the  kind who chases after women or he  isn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Mulwray isn't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never even kids about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he takes it very seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes winks. Yelburton chuckles appreciatively, loosenin up a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't happen to know where Mr.  Mulwray's having lunch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, tell him I'll be back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes spots a card tray on Yelburton's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Mind if I take one of your cards?   In case I want to get in touch with  you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes fishes a couple off the tray, puts them in his  handkerchief pocket. He goes out the door, nearly running into a man who is standing by the Secretary's desk, about GITTES' age only a head taller and a foot wider, dressed a plain suit that fits him about as well as a brown paper bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mulvihlll, what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: OUTER OFFICE
dialogues.text: Mulvihill stares at Gittes with unblinking eyes, remains the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shut my water off, what's it to  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you find out? You don't drink  it, you don't take a bath in it,  maybe they sent you a letter. Ah,  but then you'd have to be able to  read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mulvihill moves toward Gittes, shaking with fury. Yelburt steps between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Relax, Mulvihill, glad to see you. (to Yelburton) Do you know Claude Mulvihill here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope so. He's working for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rings the bell. He waits. A powerful CHINESE BUTLER with heavy hair and a half-jack of gold on one front tooth, answers the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J.J. Gittes to see Mr. Mulwray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the Chinese Butler a card from his wallet. The B takes it and disappears, leaving Gittes standing in the  doorway. Gittes stands, and sweats, watching a Japanese GARDENER t a hedge. There's a SQUEAKING SOUND. Gittes moves a few fe off the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chauffeur is washing down a cream-colored Packard with chamois. Steam rises off the hood. The squeaking has obviously com from the chamois.

dialogues.speaker: CHINESE BUTLER
dialogues.text: In doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes looks behind him. The Chinese Butler is gesturing him to follow.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Follows him, trying to check out the rooms as he goes. A  maid is cleaning in the den. They pass through it out som French doors along a trellised walkway to a large pond wi running water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wait, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes is left standing by the pond. It's suddenly very q except for the runnning water. The pond is over-flowing.  After a moment, the Gardener comes running back. He smile at Gittes, probes into the pond. There's something gleaming in the bottom of it. Gittes no it. After a moment, the Gardener drops the long probe, the wa recede.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gittes) Bad for glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not understanding) Yeah sure. Bad for glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gardener nods, and is off, leaving Gittes staring at object in the bottom of the pond that is gleaming. He looks at the tool the Gardener was using, hesitates, p it up and starts to probe into the pond himself, toward t gleaming object. He then spots Evelyn rounding a turn, coming down the  trellised pathway. He casually belts the probe, holds ont it for poise. Evelyn is wearing jeans that are lathered white on the in of the thighs and laced with brown horsehair. She's wearing riding boots, is perspiring a little, but l younger than she did in the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Gittes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes is a little taken aback at seeing Evelyn. He is an as well. Nevertheless, he is elaborately polite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I'm here to see your  husband, Mrs. Mulwray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He laughs. a little nervously. He waits for a reply. Ther is none. The Chinese Butler appears on the veranda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like something to drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you having?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iced tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Fine, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chinese Butler nods, disappears

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn sits at a glass-topped table. Gittes Joins her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My husband's at the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually he's not. And he's moved  from his apartment at the El Macando.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) That's not his apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway... I... the point is, Mrs.  Mulwray.  I'm not in business to be  loved, but I am in business, and  believe me, whoever set up your  husband, set me up. L.A.'s a small  town, people talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waits for a response. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; uneasily) I'm just trying to make a living,  and I don't want to become a local  Joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gittes, you've talked me into  it. I'll drop the lawsuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I'll drop it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The iced tea comes on a tray which Ramon sets down betwee them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; pleasantly) So let's just drop the whole thing.  Sugar?  Lemon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Mulwray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as she's mixing one  of the drinks) Yes, Mr. Gittes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to drop it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn looks up. Gittes smiles a little sheepishly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should talk this over with your  husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little concerned) Why?... What on earth for?  Look,  Hollis seems to think you're an  innocent man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've been accused of many  things, Mrs. Mulwray, but never that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again he laughs a little nervously. Again no reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) You see, somebody went to a lot of  trouble here, and I want to find  out, lawsuit or no lawsuit. I'm not  the one who's supposed to be caught  with my pants down... so I'd like to  see your husband. Unless that's a  problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a slight edge) What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I speak frankly, Mrs. Mulwray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may if you can, Mr. Gittes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (determined to be  polite) Well, that little girlfriend, she  was attractive in a cheap sort of  way of course.  She's disappeared.  Maybe they disappeared together  somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with rising anger) Suppose they did. How does it concern  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing personal, Mrs. Mulwray, I  just --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very personal. It couldn't be  more personal. Is this a business or  an obsession with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at it this way. Now this phony  broad, excuse the language, says  she's you, she's hired me. Whoever  put her up to it, didn't have anything  against me. They were out to get  your husband. Now if I see him, I  can help him.  Did you talk this  morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn brushes lightly at the horsehair on her Jeans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I went riding rather early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like you went quite a distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Just riding bareback, that's  all. Anyway, you might try the Oak  Pass or Stone Canyon Reservoirs.  Sometimes at lunch Hollis takes walks  around them. Otherwise he'll be home  by 6:30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll stop by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please call first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes drives up a winding road, following a flood channe up into the parched hills.

dialogues.speaker: TWO FIRE TRUCKS
dialogues.text: One a rescue truck, are at the entrance to the reservoir. The chain link fence with its KEEP OUT sign is open and t are people milling around. The reservoir is below. Gittes' car is stopped by a couple of UNIFORMED POLICE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, this is closed to the public,  sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes hesitates only a moment, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Guard) It's all right. Russ Yelburton, Deputy  Chief in the Department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He fishes out one of Yelburton's cards from his handkerch pocket, hands it to the Guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mr. Yelburton. Go on down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes drives past the Guards, through the gate, along th reservoir. He spots a police car and an unmarked one as w Gittes stops and gets out of the car. Several men with th backs turned, one talking quietly, staring down into the  reservoir where other men in small skiffs are apparently  dredging for something. One of the men turns and sees Gittes. He recognizes Gitte and is visibly shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes, for Chrissakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving to Gittes,  taking him by the  arm) C'mon, get out of here before --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loach tries to ease him down the path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before what? What the hell's going  on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the sound of his raised voice, a man standing at the e of the channel, talking to two boys in swimming trunks, t around. He's a tall, sleek Mexican in his early thirties, LUIS ESCOBAR. Both Gittes and Escobar register considerable surprise at seeing one another. The men around them are extremely une Loach is actually sweating. Finally, Escobar smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Jake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without smiling) How are you, Lou?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a cold I can't seem to shake  but other than that, I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Summer colds are the worst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes reaches into his pocket, pulls out his cigarette c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No smoking, sir. It's a fire hazard  this time of year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we can make an exception.  I'll see he's careful with the  matches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lighting up) Thanks, Lou.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you get past the guards?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, to tell you the truth, I lied  a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Escobar nods. They walk a couple of steps. The other poli two plainclothesmen and a uniformed officer, watch them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've done well by yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sometimes it takes a while for  a man to find himself and I guess  you have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poking around in other people's dirty  linen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Tell me, you still throw  Chinamen into jail for spitting on  the laundry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're behind the times, Jake. They've  got steam irons now. (smiles) And I'm out of Chinatown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since I made Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's apparent Gittes is impressed despite himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. So what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking for someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hollis Mulwray. You seen him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome to try. There he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Escobar points down to the reservoir. A couple of men usi poles with hooks are fishing about in the water. It can b SEEN that one of them has hooked something. He shouts. The other man hooks it, too. They pull, reveal the soaking back of a man's coat. They start to pull the  body into the skiff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are standing over the body of Mulwray. Escobar has the sh drawn back. Evelyn nods. Escobar drops the sheet. Escobar and Evelyn move a few fe to one side and whisper, almost as though they were tryin to keep the corpse from hearing them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like he was washed the entire  length of the runoff channel. Could  he swim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obviously the fall must have knocked  him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn nods slightly Escobar coughs. A coroner's assistan wheels the body out of the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) This alleged affair he was having.  The publicity didn't make him morose  or unhappy?

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE CORONER'S
dialogues.text: Gittes has been sitting on a wooden bench, smoking and  listening. At this question, he rises and looks through t doorway. Escobar sees him, ignores him. Evelyn doesn't see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well, it didn't make him happy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But there is no possibility he would  have taken his own life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sharply) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little uncomfortably  now) Mrs. Mulwray, do you happen to know  the name of the young woman in  question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn shows a flash of annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know where she might be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Escobar and Evelyn move slowly toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and your husband never discussed  her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping, faltering) He... we did... he wouldn't tell me  her name.  We quarreled over her...  of course. It came as a complete  surprise to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A complete surprise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I thought you'd hired a private  investigator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A private investigator?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing vaguely  toward the door) Mr. Gittes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn looks up to see Gittes standing in the doorway onl foot or two from her. She stops cold. They look at one an for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (her eyes on Gittes) But I... I... did that because I  thought it was a nasty rumor I'd put  an end to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She finishes, looks plaintively at Gittes. Escobar is rig at her back. Gittes says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when did Mr. Gittes inform you  that these rumors had some foundation  in fact?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn looks at Escobar but doesn't know how to answer hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smoothly) Just before the story broke in the  papers, Lou.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Escobar nods. They begin to walk slowly, again have to mo out of the way as some other corpse is being wheeled out one of the Coroner cubicles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wouldn't happen to know the  present whereabouts of the young  woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or her name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have walked a few steps further down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you need me for anything else,  Lieutenant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so, Mrs. Mulwray. Of  course you have my deepest sympathy  and if we need anymore information,  we'll be in touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll walk her to her car, be right  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn glances at Gittes. They go through a couple of out doors and pass several reporters who have been in the out hall, laughing, kidding, the tag end of lines like "only L.A." and "Southern Cafeteria." Gittes hurries her past the reporters who flank them, ask questions. Gittes brushes them aside.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN AND GITTES
dialogues.text: In a small parking lot. Evelyn fumbles in her bag, looking feverishly for somethi in her purse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Mulwray?... Mrs. Mulwray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flushed, perspiring) ...Just a minute...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (touching her gently) You left your keys in the ignition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances down, leans against the side of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Thank you for going along with me. I  just didn't want to explain  anything... I'll send you a check.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) A check?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn gets in her car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To make it official, I hired you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drives off, leaving Gittes gaping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give me that, Lou. You hauled  me down here for a statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Escobar shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It was an accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean that's what you're going to  call it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Escobar looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. (contemptuously) Out of respect for his civic position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Resume walking. Gittes laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd he do, Lou, make a pass at  your sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Escobar stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he drowned a cousin of mine with  about five hundred other people. But  they weren't very important, just a  bunch of dumb Mexicans living by a  dam. Now beat it, Gittes, you don't  come out of this smelling like a  rose, you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? Can you think of something  to charge me with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I do, you'll hear about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes nods, turns, and walks down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE MORGUE
dialogues.text: Gittes stops by a body on the table, the toe tagged with  Mulwray's name. MORTY is standing near it in a doorway to adjoining room. A RADIO is on, and with it the announceme that they're about to hear another chapter in the life of Lorenzo Jones and his devoted wife, Belle. Another Corone assistant sits at the table, listening to the radio and e a sandwich. Gittes ambles into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a cigarette dangling  out of his mouth) Jake, what're you doin' here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin', Morty, it's my lunch hour,  I thought I'd drop by and see who  died lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes picks up the sheet and pulls it back. CAMERA GETS FIRST GLIMPSE of Mulwray's body. Eyes open, the face badl cut and bruised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Ain't that something? Middle  of a drought, the water commissioner  drowns. Only in L.A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at. Mulwray) Yeah. Banged up pretty bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a long fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how are you, Morty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morty is wheeling in another body with the help of an  assistant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never better. You know me, Jake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he begins to move the body into the refrigerator, he b into a wrenching spasm of coughing. Gittes spots the othe body, lowers the sheet on Mulwray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up on cough) Yeah, so who you got there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morty pulls back the sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leroy Shuhardt, local drunk used to  hang around Ferguson's Alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morty brushes some sand from the man's face, laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Quite a character. Lately he'd been  living in one of the downtown storm  drains. Had a bureau dresser down  there and everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes has already lost interest. He starts away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drowned, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This stops Gittes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, got dead drunk, passed out in  the bottom of the riverbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The L.A. River?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little puzzled) Yeah, under Hollenbeck Bridge, what's  wrong with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes has moved back to the body, looks at it more close

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's bone dry, Morty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not completely dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well he ain't gonna drown in a  damp riverbed either, I don't care  how soused he was. That's like  drowning in a teaspoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morty shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got water out of him, Jake. He  drowned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes walks away mumbling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, this town...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's parked on an overpass. The sign HOLLENBECK BRIDGE on one of its concrete columns. Gittes looks down into the  riverbed below.

dialogues.speaker: FROM THE BRIDGE
dialogues.text: Gittes can see the muddy remains of a collapsed shack, it contents strewn down river from the bridge. Below him, ly half over the storm drain and one wall that was on the ba of the river is a sign that proclaims "OWN YOUR OWN OFFIC IN THIS BUILDING $5000 to $6000" which was used as a roof sorts. Downstream, there's the dresser, an oil drum, a Fo seat cushion, an Armour lard can, etc. The trashy remains Shuhardt's home. Gittes scrambles down the embankment and as he lands near the storm drain one shoe sinks, ankle deep into mud. Gitt pulls it out, swearing. He begins to walk a little further downstream when he hea the vaguely familiar SQUISHY CLOP of something. Clearing the bridge on the opposite side is the little Me Boy, again on his swayback horse, riding along the muddy  bank. They look at one another a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out to him) You were riding here the other day,  weren't you...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Boy doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Speak English?... Habla Ingles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally) Si.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you talk to a man here... few  days ago... wore glasses... he...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Boy nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) What did you talk about, mind my  asking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shadows of the two are very long now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally) The water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the water?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When it comes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When it comes? What'd you tell him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comes in different parts of the river.  Every night a different part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes nods. The horse snorts. The Boy rides slowly on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes scrambles up the embankment to note the direction storm drain by Hollenbeck Bridge takes. It is headed abov toward the Hollywood Hills, where the sun is setting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winding his way up a section of the Hollywood Hills. He p up on an open flood channel with the spotlight by the dri windwing.

dialogues.speaker: GITTES IN CAR
dialogues.text: Along the flood channel. It is dark now and Gittes follow the channel with the car spotlight. He turns at a fork in the road which allows him to continue following the flood channel.

dialogues.speaker: FURTHER UP
dialogues.text: The road is narrower. Gittes drives more slowly. Foliage overgrown in the channel so its bottom cannot be glimpsed

dialogues.speaker: STILL FURTHER
dialogues.text: The road is dirt. Heavy clusters of oak trees and eucalyp are everywhere. It is very still. Another turn and a pie- shaped view of a lake of lights in the city below can be  GLIMPSED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the road, bolted. It says "OAK PASS RESERVOIR. KEEP

dialogues.speaker: OUT. NO TRESPASSING."
dialogues.text: The chain-link itself actually extends over the flood cha and down into it, making access along the channel itself  impossible. Gittes backs up, turns off the motor, the car lights, the spotlight. A lone light overhead on tension wires is the sole  illumination. There is only the eerie SOUND of the tension WIRES HUMMIN Gittes gets out of the car, clubs the fence near the Floo channel itself.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE OTHER SIDE
dialogues.text: Gittes carefully works his way up through the thick Folia toward a second and large chain-link fence. Lights from t reservoir still higher above can be SEEN. Suddenly there is a GUNSHOT. Then ANOTHER. Gittes dives i the flood control channel, which is at this point about f feet deep and six feet wide. There is the SOUND of men  scurrying through the brush, coming near him, then retrea Gittes loses himself among the ivy in the channel. He waits. The men seem to have passed him by. But there i another SOUND now. An echoing growing sound. It puzzles  Gittes. He starts to lift his head to catch the direction

dialogues.speaker: GITTES IN FLOOD CONTROL CHANNEL
dialogues.text: Then he's inundated with a rush of water which pours over him, knocks off his hat, carries him down the channel, ba into its banks, as he desperately tries to grab some of t overgrowth to hang on and pull himself out. But the force the stream batters him and carries him with it until he's brought rudely to the chainlink fence. It stops him cold. He's nearly strained through it. Swearing and choking, he pulls himself out of the rushing water by means of the fence itself. Drenched, battered, he slowly climbs back over the fence makes his way toward his car.

dialogues.speaker: AT GITTES' CAR
dialogues.text: He fishes for his car keys, looks down. One shoe is missi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grumbling) Goddam Florsheim shoe, goddammit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to get into his car but Mulvihill and a SMALLER MAN stop him. Mulvihill pulling his coat down and pinning his arms, holding him tightly. The smaller man thrusts a  switchblade knife about an inch and a half up Gittes' lef nostril.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking with emotion) Hold it there, kitty cat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frozen, the knife in his nostril, the street lamp overhea gleaming on the silvery blade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a very nosey fellow, kitty  cat... you know what happens to nosey  fellows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Smaller Man actually seems to be trembling with rage  when he says this. Gittes doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Wanna guess? No? Okay, lose their  noses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a quick flick the Smaller Man pulls back on the blad laying Gittes' left nostril open about an inch further. G screams. Blood gushes down onto his shirt and coat. Gittes bends over, instinctively trying to keep the blood from getting on his clothes. Mulvihill and the Smaller Ma stare at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Next time you lose the whole thing,  kitty cat. I'll cut it off and feed  it to my goldfish, understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him you understand, Gittes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes is now groveling on his hands and knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbling) I understand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes on the ground can see only his tormentor's two-ton brown and white wing-tipped shoes, lightly freckled with blood.

dialogues.speaker: THE SHOE
dialogues.text: Comes up and lightly shoves Gittes into the ground. The S of FOOTSTEPS RETREATING, Gittes gasping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sits behind his desk, BACK TO CAMERA, not moving. Duffy s staring at nothing, Walsh moves uneasily around the room. The PHONE is RINGING. Sophie BUZZES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pressing down intercom) Yeah, Sophie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Miss Sessions calling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ida Sessions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know her. Take a number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bandage spread-eagled across Gittes' nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So some contractor wants to build a  dam and he makes a few payoffs. So  what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes turns slowly to Walsh. He lightly taps his nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Think you can nail Mulvihill? They'll  claim you were trespassing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want Mulvihill.  I want the  big boys that are making the payoffs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what'll you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue the shit out of 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. What's wrong with you guys?  Think ahead. We find 'em, sue 'em.  We'll make a killing. (a dazzling smile) We'll have dinner at Chasen's twice  a week, we'll be pissing on ice the  rest of our lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue people like that they're liable  to be having dinner with the Judge  who's trying the suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes looks irritated. The PHONE RINGS again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Ida Sessions again. She says  you know her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes picks up the phone. He winks to his boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Hello, Miss Sessions. I don't believe  we've had the pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes we have... are you alone, Mr.  Gittes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clowning a little  for the boys) Isn't everybody? What can I do for  you, Miss Sessions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walsh promptly starts to tell Duffy the Admiral Byrd stor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm a working girl, Mr. Gittes.  I didn't come in to see you on my  own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you come in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was the one who pretended to be  Mrs. Mulwray, remember?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walsh has finished off the punch line and both men are  laughing raucously. Gittes drops the mail he's been loafi through and puts his hand over the receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Duffy and Walsh) Shut the fuck up! (then back to Ida) ...Yes I remember nothing, Miss  Sessions, just going over a detail  or two with my associates... you  were saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I never expected anything to  happen like what happened to Mr.  Mulwray, the point is if it ever  comes out I want somebody to know I  didn't know what would happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand... if you could tell me  who employed you, Miss Sessions.  That could help us both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Why don't you give me your address  and we can talk this over?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Mr. Gittes. Just look in the  obituary column of today's Times...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The obituary column?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll find one of those people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Those people?' Miss Sessions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up. Gittes looks to his two men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes is seated, flips through the paper until he finds OBITUARY COLUMN, scans it, looks up, abruptly tears the c from the paper and puts it in his pocket. When he closes the paper we can SEE headlines in the left hand column: "WATER BOND ISSUE PASSES COUNCIL". Ten milli dollar referendum to go before the public. Evelyn Mulwray is standing at the table as he does so. He rises, allows her to sit.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN
dialogues.text: Gittes watches her as she removes her gloves slowly... Sh wearing dove gray gabardine, subdued, tailored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming... drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter's appeared. Evelyn is looking at Gittes' nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tom Collins with lime, not lemon,  please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn looks down and smoothes her gloves. When she looks back up she stares expectantly at Gittes. Gittes pulls out a torn envelope. The initials ECM can be SEEN in a delicate scroll on the corner of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got your check in the mall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. As I said, I was very grateful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes' fingers the envelope. He coughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Mulwray, I'm afraid that's not  good enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little embarrassed) Well, how much would you like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it. The money's fine. It's  generous but you've shortchanged me  on the story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coolly) I have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think so. Something besides your  husband's death was bothering you.  You were upset but not that upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gittes... (icily) Don't tell me how I feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drinks come. The waiter sets them down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. Look, you sue me, your husband  dies, you drop the lawsuit like a  hot potato, and all of it quicker  than wind from a duck's ass. Excuse  me. Then you ask me to lie to the  police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't much of a lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If your husband was killed it was. (meaning check) This can look like you paid me off  to withhold evidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he wasn't killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're hiding something,  Mrs. Mulwray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn remains unperturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I suppose I am... actually I  knew about the affair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you find out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He told you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) And you weren't the slightest bit  upset about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was grateful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn for the first time appears a little embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to explain that, Mrs.  Mulwray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a flash of annoyance) Look, I do matrimonial work, It's my  metiay.  When a wife tells me she's  happy her husband is cheating on her  it runs contrary to my experience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes looks significantly to Evelyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking directly at  her) She's cheating on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn doesn't reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Were you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn is clearly angry but she is controlling it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like the word 'cheat.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you have affairs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flashing) Mr. Gittes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost an outburst) Well I wouldn't run home and tell  him whenever I went to bed with  someone, if that's what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This subdues Gittes a little. Evelyn is still a little he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; more  calmly) Is there anything else you want to  know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you were when your husband  died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you don't know where you  were?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
