dialogues.text: I mean I can't tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were seeing someone, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn looks squarely at him. She doesn't deny it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For very long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see anyone for very long,  Mr. Gittes.  It's difficult for me.  Now I think you know all you need to  about me. I didn't want publicity. I  didn't want to go into any of this,  then or now. Is this all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, by the way. What's the 'C' stand  for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been fingering the envelope...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she stammers slightly) K... Cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That your maiden name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn turns into Gittes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must've had a reason to ask me  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) No. I'm just a snoop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem to have had a reason for  every other question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not for that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes suddenly turns sharply in to Evelyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving in) Do me a favor. Sit still and act  like I'm charming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn involuntarily draws back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) There's somebody here. Say something. Anything. Something like we're being  intimate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn reluctantly allows Gittes to move closer and dangl his hand in front of their faces. She stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (meaning his nose) How did it happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Been meaning to talk to you about  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Maybe putting your nose in other  people's business?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) More like other people putting their  business in my nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn actually smiles a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You son of a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes looks up and flashes his smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Match. How're you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. MATCH is swaying over the table, a plump woman with glass of whiskey in one hand, a large purse in the other, and a menacing look in her eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give me that, you son of a  bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes turns back to Evelyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly) Another satisfied client?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another satisfied client's wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me, you son of a bitch. You...  you bastard. Are you happy, are you  happy now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tries to take a swipe at Gittes with her purse. Gitte covers himself. Waiters rush over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You smug son of a bitch. My husband's  so upset he sweats all night! How do  you think that makes me feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweaty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Match swings at Gittes again and again. She catches on the nose. It hurts. He covers it, then swings his leg from under the table and deftly kicks her in the shin. Mrs. Match drops her purse and spills her drink. She grab her shin, hopping around a little. The waiters who had tr to restrain her now try to keep her from falling over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's get out of here before she  picks up her purse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They rise and move toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) Tough guy, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes looks, sees she's kidding, and nods.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE IN THE PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: Gittes' car has been brought by the parking attendant. Th attendant opens the passenger side for Evelyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. I've got my own car. The  creamcolored Packard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to attendant who  dutifully starts for  her car) Wait a minute, sonny. (to Evelyn) I think you better come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for? There's nothing more to  say. (to attendant) Get my car, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The attendant starts after it again. Gittes leans on the  open door of his car and in to Evelyn. He talks quietly b spits it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, go home. But in case you're  interested your husband was murdered.  Somebody's dumping tons of water out  of the city reservoirs when we're  supposedly in the middle of a drought,  he found out, and he was killed.  There's a waterlogged drunk in the  morgue. Involuntary manslaughter if  anybody wants to take the trouble  which they don't. It looks like half  the city is trying to cover it all  up, which is fine with me. But, Mrs.  Mulwray. (now inches from her) I goddam near lost my nose! And I  like it. I like breathing through  it. And I still think you're hiding  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn steadies herself on the open car door. She stares Gittes for a long moment. Then he gently tugs the car doo closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gittes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drives off into the Wilshire traffic, leaving Evelyn  looking after him.

dialogues.speaker: WITH ITS LETTERING
dialogues.text: "HOLLIS I. MULWRAY CHIEF ENGINEER"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes goes through the door to the Secretary. She looks She recognizes Gittes again and is not happy to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J.J. Gittes to see Mr. Yelburton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Secretary immediately gets up and goes into the inner office. Gittes turns and strolls around the office a moment. He s a photographic display of "THE HISTORY OF THE DWP. THE EA YEARS", along the wall. He stops as he spots a photo of t man with the cane Gittes had seen photos of earlier. He i standing high in the mountains, near a pass. The caption  reads "JULIAN CROSS. 1905". Cross is strikingly handsome. Gittes immediately pulls out the envelope containing Evel check. He looks at the corner of it, his thumb pressing d under the middle initial C, then he looks back to the pho The Secretary returns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Yelburton will be busy for some  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'm on my lunch hour. I'll wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's liable to be tied up  indefinitely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take a long lunch. All day  sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes pulls out a cigarette case, offers the Secretary o She refuses. He lights up and begins to hum 'The Way You  Look Tonight,' strolling along the wall looking at more  photographs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here he spots several photos of a much younger Mulwray, a with Julian Cross. One of the captions: "HOLLIS MULWRAY A
Gittes, still humming, turns to the Secretary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julian Cross worked for the water  department?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up) Yes. No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (humming, then) He did or he didn't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He owned it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes is genuinely surprised at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He owned the water department?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He owned the entire water supply for  the city?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (really surprised) How did they get it away from him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a sigh, then) Mr. Mulwray felt the public should  own the display. The water. If you'll  just read the display.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glances back, hums,  then) Mulwray? I thought you said Cross  owned the department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Along with Mr. Mulwray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were partners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (testily) Yes. Yes, they were partners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up, annoyed, and goes into Yelburton's inner off Gittes goes back to the photographs. He hears a SCRATCHIN SOUND, apparently coming from just outside the outer door He moves quickly to it, hesitates, swiftly opens the door Workmen are behind it, scraping away Mulwray's name on th outer door, looking up at Gittes in some surprise. The Secretary returns, sees the workman on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gittes) Mr. Yelburton will see you now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes nods graciously, heads on into Yelburton's office. INT. DWP В– YELBURTON & GITTES There is a subtle but perceptible difference in Yelburton attitude. He's now head of the department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gittes, sorry to keep you waiting.  These staff meetings, they just go  on and on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, must be especially tough to  take over under these circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes. Hollis was the best department  head the city's ever had. My goodness,  what happened to your nose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) I cut myself shaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ought to be more careful. That  must really smart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only when I breathe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) Only when you breathe... don't tell  me you're still working for Mrs.  Mulwray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops smiling) I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither do I, actually. But you hired  me or you hired that chippie to hire  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gittes, you're not making a bit  of sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, look at it this way, Mr.  Yelburton.  Mulwray didn't want to  build a dam and he had a reputation  that was hard to get around, so.   you decided to ruin it. Then he found  out that you were dumping water every  night. Then he was drowned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gittes! That's an outrageous  accusation.  I don't know what you're  talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Whitey Mehrholtz over at the  Times will. Dumping thousands of  gallons of water down the toilet in  the middle of a drought.  That's  news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes heads toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. Please sit down, Mr. Gittes.  We're... well, we're not anxious for  this to get around, but we have been  diverting a little water to irrigate  avocado and walnut groves in the  northwest valley. As you know, the  farmers there have no legal right to  our water, and since the drought  we've had to cut them off. The city  comes first, naturally.  But, well,  we've been trying to help some of  them out, keep them from going under.   Naturally when you divert water you  get a little runoff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, a little runoff. Where are  those orchards?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, the northwest valley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's like saying they're in Arizona.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gittes, my field men are out and  I can't give you an exact location...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a married man, am I right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard working, have a wife and kids...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to nail you. I just  want to know who put you up to it.   I'll give you a few days to think it  over. (hands him a card) Call me. I can help. Who knows?   Maybe we can lay the whole thing off  on a few big shots and you can stay  head of the department for the next  twenty years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes smiles, leaves an unsmiling Yelburton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes enters, drops his hat on Sophie's desk. Sophie tri to tell him something but Gittes goes on into his office.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN MULWRAY
dialogues.text: Is sitting, smoking. She looks up when he enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your usual salary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes moves to his desk, barely breaking stride at the s of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-five bucks daily for me, twenty  for each of my operators, plus  expenses, plus my fee if I show  results.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's sitting now. Evelyn is very pale now, obviously very shaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoever's behind my husband's death,  why have they gone to all this  trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Money. How they plan to make it by  emptying the reservoirs, that I don't  know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll pay your salary plus five  thousand dollars if you find out  what happened to Hollis and who is  involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes buzzes Sophie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophie, draw up one of our standard  forms for Mrs. Mulwray. (he leans back; to  Evelyn) Tell me, did you get married before  or after Mulwray and your father  sold the water department?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn nearly jumps at the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Your father is Julian Cross, isn't  he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. It was quite a while  after. I was just out of grade school  when they did that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you married your father's business  partner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn nods. She lights another cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; staring  at her, points to  the ashtray) You've got one going, Mrs. Mulwray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She quickly stubs one out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there something upsetting about  my asking about your father?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!... Yes, a little. You see Hollis  and my fa... my father had a falling  out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the water department, or over  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) Not over me. Why would they have a  falling out over me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (noting her nervousness) Then it was over the water department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not exactly. Well, I mean, yes. Yes  and no.  Hollis felt the public should  own the water but I don't think my  father felt that way.  Actually, it  was over the Van der Lip. The dam  that broke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. He never forgave him for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never forgave him for what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For talking him into building it, he  never forgave my father... They  haven't spoken to this day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starts a little) You sure shout that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about you? Do you and your father  get along?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sophie comes in with the form, cutting off Evelyn's reply Gittes places two copies on a coffee table in front of Ev

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign here... The other copy's for  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She signs it. When she looks back up, Gittes is staring  intently at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you thinking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up one of  copies, folding it,  putting it in his  pocket) Before this I turned on the faucet,  it came out hot and cold, I didn't  think there was a thing to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The engines make the small cabin vibrate. Gittes threads way down the tiny aisle of the eight passenger cabin, whi is full of middle-aged men in old clothes and their fishi gear. Gittes is poked by a pole, has to move along. One of the old men says something to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (above the engines) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll have to sit with the pilot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes moves forward into the cockpit, the PILOT looks up nods for Gittes to sit down, first moving a half eaten ch sandwich out of Gittes' seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taxiing down the ramp into the sea. In a moment, it kicks a spray of foam and takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The island gradually looming larger before the Pilot and  Gittes. The Pilot glances over at Gittes who, as usual, is impecc dressed. A contrast to the others on the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (above the engines) Well, you're not going fishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (winks) But that's what you told your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Pilot laughs raucously. Gittes laughs politely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lots of fellas do. Tell the little  woman they're going on a fishing  trip, then shack up with some little  twist on the island... she pretty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (abruptly) I'm going to see a man called Julian  Cross. Ever heard of him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the Pope Catholic? Who are you,  mister?... I ask because he doesn't  see a whole lot of people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm working for his daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) That right?... She used to be some  looker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She ain't exactly long in the tooth  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She must be about thirty-three, thirty- four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be thinking of a different  daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's only got one, I remember  her age, I read it in the newspapers  when she ran away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She ran away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, it was a big thing at the  time. Julian Cross' daughter. God  almighty. She was a wild little thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives a sidelong glance to Gittes, a little concerned  he's said too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Course, she settled down nicely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling a little) Well, you never know, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loosening up) That's for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd she run away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you know. She was sixteen or  seventeen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nudging him) We missed the best of it, didn't we,  pal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both men laugh a little lewdly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She ran off to Mexico. Rumor was she  was knocked up and didn't even know  who the father was. Went there to  get rid of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cross was looking for her all over  the country. Offered rewards,  everything. Felt real sorry for him,  with all his money.

dialogues.speaker: ALBACORE CLUB
dialogues.text: A pleasant but unobtrusive clapboard blue and white build on the bay overlooking the harbor. The seaplane lands. A  motor launch with a burgee of a fish flying from it turns and heads in the direction of the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes, driven in a station wagon, passes under the sign  with a cross painted below the name. The ranch itself is only partially in a valley on the isl As the wagon continues one can SEE that it is actually a  miniature California, encompassing desert, mountains and  canyon that tumble down palisades to the windward side of the sea. The wagon comes to a halt where a group of hands are clus around a corral. The circle of men drift apart, leaving J CROSS standing, using a cane for support, reedy but hands in a rough linen shirt and jeans. When he talks his stron face is lively, in repose it looks ravaged. EXT. BRIDLE PATH В– GITTES & CROSS Walking toward the main house. A classic Monterey. A hors led on a halter by another ranch hand slows down and defe in the center of the path they are taking. Gittes doesn't notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Horseshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes pauses, not certain he has heard correctly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said horseshit. (pointing) Horseshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, that's what it looks like.  I'll give you that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cross pauses when they reach the dung pile. He removes hi hat and waves it, inhales deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Love the smell of it. A lot of people  do but of course they won't admit  it. Look at the shape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes glances down out of politeness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; smiling,  almost enthusiastic) Always the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cross walks on. Gittes follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not one to let it go) Always?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Oh, damn near yes. Unless the  animal's sick or something. (stops and glances.  back) And the steam rising off it like  that in the morning. That's life,  Mr. Gittes. Life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Perhaps this preoccupation with  horseshit may seem a little perverse,  but I ask you to remember this. One  way or another, it's what I've dealt  in all my life. Let's have breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. COURTYARD VERANDA В– GITTES & CROSS AT BREAKFAST Below them is a corral where hands take Arabians, one by  one, and work them out, letting them run and literally ki up their heels. Cross' attention is diverted by the animals from time to  time. An impeccable Mexican butler serves them their main course, broiled fish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, you've got a nasty  reputation, Mr. Gittes. I like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dubious) Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you were a bank president that  would be one thing, but in your  business it's admirable. And it's  good advertising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's why you attract a client like  my daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm surprised you're still working  for her, unless she's suddenly come  up with another husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. She happens to think the last  one was murdered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cross is visibly surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did she get that idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I gave it to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cross nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Oh I hope you don't mind. I  believe they should be served with  the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes glances down at the fish whose isinglass eye is gl over with the heat of cooking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, as long as you don't serve  chicken that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Tell me. What do the police say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're calling it an accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the investigating officer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lou Escobar В– he's a Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We worked in Chinatown together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you call him a capable man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Far as it goes. Of course he has to  swim in the same water we all do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, but you've got no reason  to think he's bungled the case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's too bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It disturbs me, Mr. Gittes. It makes  me think you're taking my daughter  for a ride. Financially speaking, of  course. How much are you charging  her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carefully) My usual fee, plus a bonus if I come  up with any results.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sleeping with her? Come,  come, Mr. Gittes. You don't have to  think about that to remember, do  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want an answer to that question  I can always put one of my men on  the job. Good afternoon, Mr. Cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Gittes!  You're dealing with a  disturbed woman who's lost her  husband. I don't want her taken  advantage of. Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may think you know what you're  dealing with, but believe me, you  don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This stops Gittes. He seems faintly mused by it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is that funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's what the D.A. used to tell me  about Chinatown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was he right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...Exactly what do you know about  me, Mr. Gittes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mainly that you're rich and too  respectable to want your name in the  papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grunts, then) 'Course I'm respectable. I'm old. Politicians, ugly buildings and whores  all get respectable if they last  long enough. I'll double whatever  your fees are and I'll pay you ten  thousand dollars if you can find  Hollis' girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, his girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean the little chippie he was  with at the El Macando?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. She's disappeared, hasn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't that strike you as odd?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. She's probably scared to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't it be useful to talk to  her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Mulwray was murdered, she was  probably one of the last people to  see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't see Mulwray much, did  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When was the last time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cross starts to reply, then there's the SOUND of a MARIAC BAND and some men in formation clear a bluff about a hund yards off. They are dressed like Spanish dons on horsebac For the most part they are fat in the saddle and pass alo in disordered review to the music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheriff's gold posse... bunch of  damn fools who pay $5,000 apiece to  the sheriff's reelection. I let 'em  practice up out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Do you remember the last time  you talked to Mulwray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cross shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At my age, you tend to lose track...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, It was about five days ago.  You were outside the Pig 'n Whistle  and you had one hell of an argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cross looks to Gittes in some real surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) I've got the photographs in my office.  If they'll help you remember. What  was the argument about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a long pause, then:) My daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just find the girl, Mr. Gittes. I  think she is frightened and I happen  to know Hollis was fond of her. I'd  like to help her if I can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't realize you and Hollis were  so fond of each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cross looks hatefully at Gittes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hollis Mulwray made this city and he  made me a fortune... We were a lot  closer than Evelyn realized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want to hire me, I still have  to know what you and Mulwray were  arguing about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (painfully) Well... she's an extremely jealous  person. I didn't want her to find  out about the girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you find out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've still got a few teeth in my  head, Mr. Gittes, and a few friends  in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. My secretary'll send you a  letter of agreement. Tell me are you  worried about that girl, or what  Evelyn might do to her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just find the girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll look into it as soon as I check  out some avocado groves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avocado groves?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be in touch, Mr. Cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark and quiet except for the whirring of fans. Gittes  approaches one of the CLERKS at a desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a little lost. Where can I find  the plat books for the northwest  valley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Clerk's droopy eyes widen a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Part of it's in Ventura County. We  don't have Ventura County in our  Hall of Records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which is a snotty remark. Gittes smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll settle for L.A. County.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (regards him, then) Row twenty-three, section C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Clerk turns away abruptly. Gittes regards his back a  moment, then goes to the stacks.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE STACKS
dialogues.text: Gittes sees the Clerk turn to another, say something. The second clerk gets on the phone. Gittes watches a moment,  then swiftly turns his attention to the stacks. He hauls down the northwest valley volume, opens it. It's huge and there's a lot to go through. The print itself makes him squint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showing TRACT, LOT, PARCEL, even a METES AND BOUNDS  designation where the description of the land parcel is l and hopelessly involved e.g. '6000 paces to Rio Seco, the 7000 paces to Loma Linda, etc.' These descriptions are ol and faded. In the owners' column, however there are numer freshly typed names pasted over the prior owners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hauls the huge volume back to the  Clerk's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Clerk) Say... uh... sonny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Clerk turns sharply around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come all these new names are  pasted into the plat book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Land sales out of escrow are always  recorded within the week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes looks a little surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then these are all new owners?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (astonished) But that means that most of the  valley's been sold in the last few  months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that's what it says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I check one of these volumes  out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly snotty) Sir, this is not a lending library,  it's the Hall of Records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then, how about a ruler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ruler?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The print's pretty fine. I forgot my  glasses. I'd like to be able to read  across.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The exasperated Clerk reaches around, rummages, slaps a r on the desk. Gittes goes back to the stacks with the ruler. He opens t book, places the ruler not horizontally but vertically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beside the OWNER column he places the ruler, looks toward the clerks, then swiftly rips down the page, tearing out strip about two inches wide containing the owner's name a property description. As he tears, he either sniffles or  coughs to cover the SOUND of the PAPER being ripped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amidst a hall of shimmering dust and heat, parched and dr groves, narrower roads. He passes a ramshackle home, next to a rotting orchard. T is a "SOLD" sign on the collapsing barn. Gittes stops, ch it against the names he had taken from the Hall of Record

dialogues.speaker: OLD STUCCO BUILDINGS FURTHER ON
dialogues.text: And a few withered pepper trees. Gittes has paused at thi dried-up intersection. There is a "SOLD" sign on a drug s Gittes looks OFF SCREEN. Coming INTO VIEW above the arid fields is a spiraling clo of purple smoke. Gittes heads in that direction. Gittes parks at the edge of the field. About twenty yards away is a man mounted on a strange machine, holding a lid off it. Billowing lavender clouds are belching forth. Several CHILDREN are watching the man at work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to one of the Children) Say, pal, what's he doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Making some rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes nods, walks over to the man who is elaborately bus himself with the intricacies of his machine. He's aware o Gittes watching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're just the man I'm looking  for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rainmaker now glances down at Gittes, who as usual is immaculately dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some associates and I are thinking  of buying property out here. Of  course, we're worried about the  rainfall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rainmaker steps down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem with me on the Job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. (glancing around at  the desolate, dry  field) Do you have any references?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAINMAKER & GITTES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: City of La Habra Heights filled an  800,000 gallon reservoir with sixteen  inches of rain in two days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) That's swell. But how about here? (pulling out names  from his pocket) Ever worked for Robert Knox, Emma  Dill, Clarence Speer, Marian Parsons,  or Jasper Lamar Crabb?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never heard of 'em... new owners?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (climbing back up) Lot of turnover these days. Better  tell them to get in touch with me if  they want to hang onto their land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'll do that.

dialogues.speaker: GITTES DRIVING
dialogues.text: Is now covered with a film of dust: He reaches a fork in the dirt road. There are a couple of mailboxes. Gittes takes this fork and begins a slow ascent. As he does, the tops of a line of bright green trees can SEEN, coming more and more INTO VIEW, row upon row of avo and walnut groves, their foliage heavy. The few structure in the distance are white-washed, and well kept, right do to the white-washed stones that mark the pathway to the h Towering above it all is a huge wooden water tank. Gittes drives through a gate that has "NO TRESPASSING" an "KEEP OUT PRIVATE PROPERTY" signs neatly printed on it. He drives down the road into the grove.

dialogues.speaker: GITTES
dialogues.text: Pulls to a halt in the road flanking the orchard lanes. H puts the car in neutral, stares at the trees. By contrast with what he has seen they are lush and beautiful, their  heavy branches barely swaying in a light breeze. Then a SHOTGUN BLAST abruptly strips bare the branches of the tree he'd been staring at.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes is shocked. He looks behind him. Riding on horseba down the field in the direction he had just driven is a R Faced Man in overalls. His hat blows off his head. He doe not, however, lose the shotgun he has just used. Gittes'  lane of retreat is denied him. He guns the car, and takes off down one of the orchard lanes.

dialogues.speaker: GITTES
dialogues.text: The dirt lane is rough. As Gittes nears the end of it, a  Younger Man on a mule blocks the exit. Gittes veers a sharp left, knocking a branch off one of t trees, heading down one of the cross-lanes. Here he's pur by a scraggly dog that nips at the tires. Gittes yells at it.

dialogues.speaker: GROVE
dialogues.text: Two farmers on foot, one using a crutch, run down the lan toward a dust trail rising above the trees. They've spott it. Clearly it's from Gittes' car. This hide-and-seek chase between one man on horseback, on on a mule and a couple on foot continues up and down and  across the orchard lanes until Gittes' front tire and rad are ruptured by another SHOTGUN BLAST. Gittes' car veers off, scattering a stray gaggle of geese and smacks into an avocado tree, shaking loose a barrage the heavy fruit onto Gittes and the car. Gittes immediately tries to get out through the branches  over the back of his car, but he's pulled off it by one o the younger farmers, a huge brute who he begins to tussle with. The Crippled Farmer begins to bang Gittes on the ba with his crutch. The two of them manage to pound Gittes t the ground within moments, where the Crippled Farmer cont to whack away at Gittes with the crutch. The older Red Faced Farmer with the shotgun and the Man o mule ride up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, quit it! Quit now! Search  the man, see if he's armed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes is hefted half off the ground and the two younger  Farmers spin him around, going through his clothes. Gitte is badly banged up and half out on his feet. They toss hi wallet, his silver cigarette case, etc. on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said see if he's armed, not empty  his pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He ain't armed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes leans against the back of his car, breathing heavi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, mister. Who you with?  Water department or the real estate  office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes' back is to the Red Faced Farmer. He has trouble  catching his breath. The Crippled Farmer pokes him rudely the back with his crutch. Gittes turns sharply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Crippled Farmer) Get away from me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Answer him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Touch me with that thing again and  you'll need a pair of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shoving Gittes) Whyn't you pick on somebody your own  size?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said cut that out! Give him a chance  to say something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes looks up at the Red Faced Farmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaching down for  his wallet) Name's Gittes. I'm a private  investigator and I'm not with either  one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what are you doing out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Client hired me to see... whether or  not the water department's been  irrigating your land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irrigating my land? (exploding) The water department's been sending  you people to blow up my water tanks!  They threw poison down three of my  wells! I call that a funny way to  irrigate. Who'd hire you for a thing  like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes reaches into his pocket. The paper's on the ground He picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Evelyn Mulwray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mulwray? That's the son of a bitch  who's done it to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mulwray's dead. You don't know what  you're talking about, you dumb Oakie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Big Farmer takes a swing at Gittes. Gittes kicks him  squarely in the nuts, knees him in the jaw after he's dou up, and hits him solidly. The Crippled Farmer takes caref aim and brings his crutch down on the back of Gittes' hea Gittes is knocked to the ground and lies still beside the Big Farmer who is writhing in agony in the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's that.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK SCREEN
dialogues.text: There's a PURLING SOUND, which soon becomes defined into SOUND OF VOICES talking quietly В– about whether to move not to move, doctors, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is staring down at Gittes who's lying in the screened in  porch of the farmers. His wife, the Red Faced Farmer, and the Big Farmer are there, along with the dog. The Red Faced Farmer's wife has set tea out. The farmers, all of them, now seem awkward and a little embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: DUSK
dialogues.text: He focuses on Evelyn who sits right next to him. He's got dried blood down the side of his face from his nose, a hu mouse on his cheek, and his clothes are torn in a couple spots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Evelyn) What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, almost as  if he were in a  hospital) You didn't look too good, so we  thought we better call your employer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes nods. He checks his watch. He looks out. It's almo evening. Gittes says nothing. The wife of the Red Faced Farmer (DU looks reproachfully at Dubois. Gittes feels the back of h head, It obviously hurts him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn and Gittes go out to her car, the cream colored  Packard. Dubois accompanies them, along with the Big Farmer who is carrying a crate of something. Gittes has cleaned himself a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look here, if it's all the same with  you, we'll get your car patched up.  If you'll tell me what your trousers  run you, I'll make good on them, Mr.  Gittes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay, Mr. Dubois.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Evelyn) It's just that they're after everybody  out here, tearing up our irrigation  ditches trying to make our land  worthless so they can pick it up for  twenty-five dollars an acre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Anyway. Earl here is sorry, too. He  wants to give you something to take  back with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes looks. Earl has the huge crate he's holding brim-f of avocados.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Earl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. CAR В– EVELYN & GITTES В– DUSK Evelyn driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for coming...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes pulls out cigarette case, takes one, offers one to Evelyn who refuses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That dam is a con job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What dam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one your husband opposed. They're  conning L.A. into building it, only  the water won't go to L.A. It'll go  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Valley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything you can see, everything  around us. I was at the Hall of  Records today. (whips out papers,  turns on the car  light) That bother you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking over papers) In the last three months, Robert  Knox has bought 7,000 acres, Emma  Dill 12,000 acres, Clarence Speer  5,000 acres, and Jasper Lamar Crabb  25,000 acres.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jasper Lamar Crabb?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I think I'd remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. They've been blowing these  farmers out of here and buying their  land for peanuts. Have any idea what  this land'll be worth with a steady  water supply? About thirty million  more than they paid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Hollis knew about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's why he was killed. Jasper Lamar  Crabb. Jasper Lamar Crabb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's pulling out his wallet, excitedly now, spilling its  contents onto the seat. He pulls out the obituary column  he'd folded up earlier in the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) We got it. We got it, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a memorial service at the  Mar Vista Inn today for Jasper Lamar  Crabb. He died three weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that unusual?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two weeks ago he bought those 25,000  acres. That's unusual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn's car pulls up before the elegant Spanish rest hom its entryway illuminated by streetlights. There is a smal sign giving the name of the place in elegant neon scroll. sits on the rolling green lawns. Gittes gets out of the car with Evelyn. He offers her his arm and they go up the walkway to the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes and Evelyn are approached by an unctuous man in hi forties, with a flower in his buttonhole. He sees Evelyn  first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello there, I'm Mr. Palmer. Can I  help you folks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he gets a clear look at Gittes, bruised, trousers to etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I sure hope so. It's Dad. (indicating his  disheveled appearance) I just can't handle him anymore, can  I, sweetheart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my goodness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hastily) Nothing to do with Dad. It's me,  actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They just don't get along very well.  Dad's a lamb with anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not so sure) Oh, well, I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naturally, I want the best for him,  money is no object.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps if we could meet your father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's just one question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you accept anyone of the Jewish  persuasion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn can't quite conceal her surprise at the question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very embarrassed) I'm sorry. We don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smoothly) Don't be sorry, neither does Dad.  Wanted to make sure though, didn't  we, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn stares back at Gittes, amused and appalled. She ma to nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just to be certain, I wonder if you  could show us a list of your patients?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (polite but pointed) We don't reveal the names of our  guests as a matter of policy. I know  you'd appreciate that if your father  came to live with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes locks eyes with Palmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confidentially) That's exactly what we wanted to  hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder, is it too late for us to  have a look around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so. Be happy to show  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind if we took a stroll  on our own?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just, if you will, confine yourself  to the main building. It's nearly  bedtime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We understand, c'mon, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes Evelyn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking. Either by accident or design, the primarily  octogenarian guests have segregated themselves. In one wi the men are playing pinochle, some are playing dominoes, elderly gentleman sits by himself carefully peeling an or In an adjacent parlor several white-headed ladies work on quilt. Gittes grabs Evelyn's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly) They're all here. Every goddam name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes points to the wall. It says "ACTIVITIES BOARD". Th are titles. "LAWN BOWLING". "BRIDGE". "FISHING". "CROQUET Below them are the names of the guests, entered under cer activities, for certain days. After Evelyn looks, she turns to Gittes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; indicating  the ancients around  them) You're looking at the owners of a  50,000 acre empire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (astonished) They can't be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They may not know it but they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes strolls toward the women knitting and working on t quilt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two of the ladies giggle. The third continues to busy her with her quilt, off by herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Which one of you is Emma Dill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two of them say "she is," and point in different directio The third gives them a curt look and goes back to her  knitting. Gittes approaches her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Emma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some old voice is singing softly, "Don't Sit Under the Ap Tree."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been wanting to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know that you're a very  wealthy woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stitching, smiles) I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you own a lot of land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not anymore. Oh, some time ago, my  late husband owned a good deal of  beach property in Long Beach, but we  lost it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes looks at the quilt. In it is the head of a fish am the rest of the crazy quilt pattern. Gittes spots it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just lovely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks through the quilt for other pieces of the fish,  comes across the tail and by it the initials A.C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating tail) Where did you get this material?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (what it sounds like) The apple core club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The apple core?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. The albacore. It's a fish. My  grandson's a member and they take  very nice care of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do they do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give us things. Not just some old  flag like this, but В–-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (kneeling) But what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're a sort of unofficial charity  of theirs, Mr. Gittes. Would you  care to come this way? Someone wants  to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes looks up, sees Palmer standing in the doorway, loo taut and a little drawn. Evelyn is beside him. She gestur as if there's someone behind Palmer. Gittes rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you later, Emma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks toward Palmer who waits for him to walk in front

dialogues.speaker: AT THE ENTRANCE HALL
dialogues.text: Is waiting. He's got his hand in his pocket. Evelyn looks Gittes. The four of them stand there, Mulvihill towering over  everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on I want you to meet somebody,  Gittes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing from Palmer  to Mulvihill) Can we leave the lady out of this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little uncertain) Yeah, why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'd like to walk her to her  car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking her by the  arm) Get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see she makes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mulvihill has walked up beside Gittes. He makes the mista of opening the glass door in the entryway, putting his ba to Gittes for a moment. Gittes swiftly pulls Mulvihill's  jacket up over his head. He spins him around. With his ja covering his face, Gittes hammers away at Mulvihlll, beat him against the glass door, along the wall, mercilessly  pounding his fists into the cloth until the cloth turns r and Mulvihill begins to sink to the red tile floor. Palmer screams. Evelyn stands there astonished. Mulvihill gun has clattered to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as Mulvihill hits  the floor, to Evelyn) What are you waiting for? Get in the  car!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn goes. Mulvihill tries to get up again. Palmer starts to go for gun, nearly picking it up. Gittes slaps it out of his han and kicks it. It goes flying down the hall, at least thirty feet; hits wall. Palmer goes screaming off into the night. Gittes turns ba to Mulvihill who starts to get up, then collapses. Gittes goes out the front door, ignoring the excited audi of ancients behind him.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: As Gittes walks down the pathway, he stops. Two men are c toward him. One of them is shorter, and has the nervous,  jerky moves of the man who slit his nose. Gittes stops. The two men fan out and continue to move to him. Gittes spots the two-tone shoes. He begins to back up. Suddenly there is a pair of headlights flashing brilliant behind the two men. In a moment Evelyn's car is headed ac the lawn directly toward the two men, accelerating as it  gets near them. They look in disbelief, then dive for saf The car skids to a stop, fishtailing a little on the gras Evelyn opens the passenger door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes jumps in and she takes off across the lawn, tiltin the elegant little neon sign on the lawn as she goes. Two SHOTS ARE FIRED. INT. CAR В– EVELYN & GITTES Evelyn looking straight ahead, driving. After a moment sh takes one hand off the wheel and rubs her left eye a litt Gittes watches her. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes stands on the veranda, smoking a cigarette, starin off into the night. Evelyn comes out to the veranda, carrying a tray with whi and an ice bucket on it. She sets it down. Gittes turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (watching her pour) Maid's night off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little surprised,  he laughs) What do you mean, 'why?' Nobody's  here, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing Gittes his  drink) I gave everybody the night off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy, it's an innocent question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No question from you is innocent,  Mr. Gittes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing) I guess not to you, Mrs. Mulwray.  Frankly you really saved my a... my  neck tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me something. Does this usually  happen to you, Mr. Gittes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that, Mrs. Mulwray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm only judging on the basis  of one afternoon and an evening, but  if that's how you go about your work,  I'd say you're lucky to get through  a whole day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pouring himself  another drink) Actually this hasn't happened to me  in some time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When was the last time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just. I don't know why. I'm asking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes touches his nose, winces a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was in Chinatown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you doing there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking a long drink) Working for the District Attorney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doing what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes looks sharply at her. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As little as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The District Attorney gives his men  advice like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do in Chinatown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him. Gittes stares off into the night. Evelyn has poured herself another drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bothers you to talk about it, doesn't  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I wonder... could I. Do you have  any peroxide or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He touches his nose lightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sure. C'mon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes his hand and leads him back into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes pulls the plaster off his nose, stares at it in th mirror. Evelyn takes some hydrogen peroxide and some cotton out o medicine cabinet. Evelyn turns Gittes' head toward her. S has him sit on the pullman tile adjacent to the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor did a nice job...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She begins to work on his nose with the peroxide. Then sh sees his cheek, checks back in his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) Boy oh boy, you're a mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (working on him) So why does it bother you to talk  about it... Chinatown...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bothers everybody who works there,  but to me... It was...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold still. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't always tell what's going  on there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...No. Why was it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I was keeping someone from  being hurt and actually I ended up  making sure they were hurt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you do anything about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're very close now as she's going over a mouse very n his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Make sure I don't find myself  in Chinatown anymore. Wait a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes hold of her and pulls her even closer,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (momentarily freezing) What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring intently) There's something black in the green  part of your eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not moving) Oh that... It's a flaw in the iris...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...A flaw...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she almost shivers) ...Yes, sort of a birthmark...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes kisses her lightly, gradually rises until he's sta holding her. She hesitates, then wraps her arms around hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a nightstand, city lights visible through the open win behind it. It is RINGING. Evelyn's arm reaches INTO SHOT. SOUND of something hitting the headboard. Gittes moans. VIEW SHIFTS TO INCLUDE Gittes in bed, holding his head, w he's just hit. Evelyn pauses in her reach to the phone. S turns to him, whispers, "I'm sorry," kisses him on the he and lips. PHONE CONTINUES TO RING. She picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello... (in Spanish now) No, no, I'll come and help, just  keep watching her and don't do  anything until I get there... 'bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VIEW SHIFTS AGAIN TO INCLUDE Gittes in bed, watching Evel next to him as she's talking on the phone. She hangs up. touches Gittes' cheek lightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes stares at her silently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just... I have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I want to know where.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she starts out of  bed) Please don't be angry... believe me,  it's got nothing to do with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping her) Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (near tears) Please!... Trust me this much... (she kisses him lightly) I'll be back. Look, there is something  I should tell you. The fishing club  that old lady mentioned, the pieces  off the flag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Albacore Club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has to do with my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He owns it. You know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting up straight) You saw my fa... father? When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (panicked) You didn't tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There hasn't been a lot of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaps out of bed, throwing on a robe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he say? (insistent) What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That you were jealous, and he was  worried about what you might do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do? To who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mulwray's girlfriend, for one thing.  He wanted to know where she was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn starts quickly for the bathroom, then comes back a kneels by the side of the bed, takes Gittes' hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to listen to me. My father  is a very dangerous man. You don't  know how dangerous. You don't know  how crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me an example.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may think you know what's going  on, but you don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what your father said. You're  telling me he's in back of this whole  thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Including the death of your husband?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's possible. Please don't ask me  any more questions now. Just wait,  wait for me. I'll be back. I need  you here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses him, rushes to the bathroom, shuts the door. G stares at it a moment. Then leaps out of bed, rummages ar tosses on his trousers. He grabs his shoes, throws them o Then hurries out of the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Running across the driveway to the garage. There are two  cars there. Mulwray's Buick and Evelyn's Packard. Gittes moves over to the Buick, opens the passenger's doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Checks the ignition. No key is in it. He pulls a couple o wires from under the dash, starts to mess with them, seem satisfied. Slides out across the seat, slams the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes hurries over to the Packard. He gets down on the  driveway, lying on his back, bracing himself. With the he of his shoe, he kicks at the right rear taillight of the  car. He shatters the red lens, gets up. He carefully pull the red lens off the taillight, exposing the white light  beneath it. He tosses the red lens into the shrubbery and hurries back toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: ONE RED AND ONE WHITE TAILLIGHT
dialogues.text: Evelyn's car speeds along the curves on Sunset Boulevard, the red and white lights coming IN AND OUT OF VIEW.

dialogues.speaker: GITTES DRIVING
dialogues.text: Behind the wheel of Mulwray's car, keeping a healthy dist from Evelyn in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: EVELYN'S PACKARD
dialogues.text: Pulls up before a small little bungalow house. She gets o looks up and down the street. There is nothing. She hurri on up the walkway to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN THE STREET
dialogues.text: Idles the engine with the lights off. He brings the car a few yards further down the street, parking it near Evelyn Gittes gets out of the car and goes up the walkway. The  curtains are drawn except for one of the small windows on the side of the house. He goes to it and looks, balancing on the edge of the por

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: Gittes sees Evelyn's Oriental servant rush through the li room of the small house. In a moment he re-emerges back  through the living room carrying a tray with a glass and  pitcher on it.

dialogues.speaker: GITTES
dialogues.text: Around to the side of the house. He runs into shrubbery a a short picket fence. He climbs over it, follows along the stucco wall to a ser of windows at the corner of the house. These all have sha on them. He can hear someone crying in the house. Someone else tal alternately firmly and plaintively in Spanish. Here the  windows have blinds. He moves to one where the blind is n completely drawn. There's an inch or so of space at the bottom.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: Gittes can see the servant again. Evelyn is pacing back a forth in and out of his line of vision. After a moment so rises INTO SHOT, obviously from lying on a bed. The figur is just a few feet from Evelyn. Her tear-stained face com INTO VIEW. It is unmistakably the girl Gittes had last se with Hollis Mulwray. Mulwray's girlfriend. She's looking up to Evelyn, speakin in Spanish. Her words are not discernible but the tone is bitter, anguished. A newspaper is strewn about the room. Evelyn kneels. She insists that the girl swallow down som pills. The girl reluctantly does.

dialogues.speaker: GITTES
dialogues.text: Continues to watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emerges from the house, goes to her car and gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn sees Gittes sitting in her car, staring coldly at  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, give me the keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned, furious) You bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's either that or you drive to the  police yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Mrs. Mulwray. You've got your  husband's girlfriend tied up in there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not tied up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I mean. You're keeping  her there against her will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let's go talk to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes starts to get out of the car. Evelyn grabs his arm nearly screaming:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her intensity actually rips Gittes' already partially tor jacket. He looks at it and her. It seems to have a momentary calm effect on both of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) She's too upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hollis' death. I tried to keep it  from her, I didn't want her upset  before I could make plans for her to  leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean she just found out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what it looks like, Mrs.  Mulwray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does it look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like she knows about Hollis' death.  Like she knows more than you want  her to tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes explodes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just tell me the truth. I'm not the  police. I don't care what you've  done. I'm not going to hurt you, but  one way or another I'm going to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't go to the police if I tell  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will if you don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long pause. Evelyn's head sinks onto the steering wheel her hair covering her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's my sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evelyn is breathing very deeply now. Not crying, but the  kind of deep breathing that comes from real hysteria. Git puts an arm on her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy... If it's your sister  it's your sister... why all the  secrecy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lifts her head and looks up at him. He's genuinely  puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (really upset) I can't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because of Hollis? Because she was  seeing your husband? Was that it?  Jesus Christ, say something. Was  that it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods. Gittes sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally) I would never ever have harmed Hollis.  I loved him more than my own family.  He was the most gentle, decent man  imaginable... and he put up with  more from me than you'll ever know...  I just wanted him to be happy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She begins to cry softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a moment) I took your husband's Buick... (he opens the car  door) I'll return it tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you coming back with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I'm not telling anybody  about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...That's not what I meant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a long moment of silence. Gittes looks over to  Evelyn. Her hair covers most of her face from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally) Yeah, well... I'm very tired, Mrs.  Mulwray. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets out and slams the car door. She drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spray is hitting him full on the top of the head. Git is so exhausted he's literally holding onto the nozzle as the water pours down. He shuts the shower off, reaches we for a towel, dabs his nose lightly with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pads around in elegant silk pajamas. He walks over to the window where morning light is stream in. He closes the curtains, collapses on the bed, on top the covers, inert. Almost immediately the PHONE RINGS. Gi lets it go on for a moment, then picks it up without sayi anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (male) Gittes?... Gittes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ida Sessions wants to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ida Sessions, you remember Ida.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes slowly rises to one elbow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?... I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, tell you what, pal. If Ida  wants to see me she can call me at  my office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up, falls back down. PHONE RINGS AGAIN. AND AGAI Gittes swears, picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 684 1/2 East Tensington. Echo Park.  She begged me to call. She's waiting  for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Gittes can say anything, the phone clicks dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes pulls up. It is a bungalow courtyard with a very n walkway and sickly green stucco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes at the front door. It's slightly ajar. He knocks.  Nothing. He opens it and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning light filters through the half-open blinds. Dust  particles in the shafts of light. It's still and empty. G sees something down the hall, under the legs of a telepho table. Gittes moves toward it. It is grotesque. When he g closer he can see it's a wilted head of lettuce. Just ins the kitchen some radishes and onions lie on the linoleum. Gittes walks on into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clearing the kitchen counter, Gittes sees IDA SESSIONS ly on her back on the floor, surrounded by the groceries fro broken bag. Ice cream has melted around her. Her eyes are open, a str of ants is moving across the ice cream and into her mouth She's recognizable as the woman who posed as Evelyn Mulwr Gittes kneels over her. He gingerly opens her handbag, fi for its contents, takes them and looks at them on the kit counter. Wallet with a few bills in it, driver's license with her  name. A Screen Actors Guild card. Gittes nods, turns,  carefully replaces the items in the purse. He idly opens the broom closet, pantry, and even Frigidai which is all but empty. Then he steps over her body and m across the hall to a door that is slightly ajar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gittes enters and turns on the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find anything interesting, Gittes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Escobar and another PLAINCLOTHED MAN stand in the bathroo by the entrance to the bedroom door. Gittes turns around. THIRD MAN is now coming down the hall from the bedroom. Gittes looks at the two, doesn't reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jerk of his head  toward the kitchen) How do you happen to know her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning toward other  room) Let me show you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
